title: Between 1 January 2019 and 31 December 2019, will an armed group from Zimbabwe engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Zimbabwe?
preds: Surprised how things are looking - would have thought there’d be a positive bounce after Mugabe but he really left the cupboards bare...The kleptocrat, his family, and various hangers on will be emptying the cupboards for years with their generous “pension”.
Recent events im Zimbabwe make me believe that it is possible scenario.

Still think it’s low but worth keeping an eye on...
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/jan/20/zimbabwe-warns-brutal-crackdown-foretaste-of-things-to-come
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-46938679
Simbabwe is severely divided (Zapu vs Zanu).

The country is fatigued with death and violence. The will be a necessary focus on the resuscitation of the moribund  economy. Violence rising to the level of 1000 dead will not occur in Zimbabewe in 2019.
                                                                                                Old Thumper
Early Warning base rate is 5% No recent mention on Genocide Watch. ACLED civilian data for the last few years is low double digits per month.

ZANU-PF continues to have a strong hold in Zimbabwe, strife in the country has tended to be a function of tribal roots since and even before independence. During and after significant economic challenges and rampant inflation open rebellion did not arise. Given the new president and the short remaining timeline for this question it is highly unlikely that Zimbabwe will see an armed group make any large scale systematic attack on civilians.  Recent military violence against fuel protests is consistent with the Mugabe era of targeted violence against opposition by military and ZANU-PF local actors. Mnangagwa's response will be telling to see if there is a shift from Mugabe era. Still I doubt any large scale systematic civilian deaths will occur - it would defy the direction Mnangagwa must take nationally and internationally to re-establish Zimbabwe economically.
Recovering from the exit of one of the world's most enduring tyrants is not a period in which I would expect that sort of domestic strife.
